criteria: Representing Fractions on a Number Line
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of fraction equivalence.
Student struggles to identify equivalent fractions and cannot explain why they are equivalent.
Student can identify some equivalent fractions but has difficulty explaining the reasoning behind their equivalence.
Student can identify equivalent fractions and provides a basic explanation of their equivalence, but the explanation may lack precision.
Student accurately identifies equivalent fractions and provides a clear explanation of their equivalence using visual models or number lines.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of fraction equivalence and can explain the concept using multiple representations and contexts.
Student is unable to compare fractions or reason about their size.
Student attempts to compare fractions but uses incorrect strategies or arrives at incorrect conclusions.
Student can compare some fractions with like numerators or denominators but struggles with fractions that have unlike numerators and denominators.
Student can compare fractions using benchmark fractions or common denominators but struggles to explain their reasoning.
Student accurately compares fractions and provides a logical explanation of their relative size using benchmark fractions, common denominators, or visual models.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of fraction comparison and can justify their reasoning using multiple strategies and representations.
Student cannot represent fractions on a number line.
Student attempts to represent fractions on a number line but places them inaccurately.
Student can represent some fractions on a number line but struggles with fractions that are close in value or have large denominators.
Student can accurately represent fractions on a number line but may not label them clearly or explain their placement.
Student accurately represents fractions on a number line, labels them clearly, and explains their placement in relation to other fractions and whole numbers.
Student demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of fraction representation on a number line and can use it to compare and order fractions effectively.
